questions.text:
A 55-year-old female patient presents with complaints of fatigue and severe itching throughout her body. Liver function test shows the following values. A liver biopsy is taken for histopathological examination which is given below. Which of the following is false about this condition?

Aspartate Aminotransferase (AST) - 129 U/L

Alanine Aminotransferase (ALT) - 33 U/L

Alkaline phosphatase (ALP) - 194 U/L

Gamma-glutamyl transferase (GGT) - 52 U/L

Total Bilirubin - 0.8 mg/dL

choices.text: Mallory-Denk bodies are seen on histopathology
Serology is positive for anti-mitochondrial antibodies
It is associated with inflammatory bowel disease
Ursodeoxycholic acid slows progression in early disease

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario showing a female patient with increased GGT and ALP and histopathology showing characteristic florid duct lesion is suggestive of primary biliary cirrhosis (PBC) which is associated with Sjogren syndrome in >70% of the cases and is not associated with inflammatory bowel disease.

She is said to suffer from PBC because of the following reasons

  • PBC has a strong female preponderance and the median age is around 50 years at the time of diagnosis
  • They present with fatigue and intense pruritus
  • Amond the liver enzymes, GGT and ALP are significantly elevated with only mild elevation of AST and ALT enzymes
  • 90% of the patients will have anti-mitochondrial antibodies (AMA)
  • Liver biopsy shows a florid duct lesion (as given in the image), which is considered diagnostic. This is due to the destruction of interlobular bile ducts with lymphoplasmacytic inflammation with or without granuloma formation.

It is associated with feathery degeneration and ballooned, bile-stained hepatocytes with prominent Mallory-Denk bodies as seen in chronic duct obstruction.

Early-stage disease is treated with oral ursodeoxycholic acid which greatly slows down progression. The mechanism of action is not entirely known but is related to it's ability to alter the biochemical composition of bile. It is not effective in late-stage disease and for these patients, liver transplantation is the best form of treatment.

Associated conditions in PBC:

  • Sjogren syndrome
  • Hashimoto's thyroiditis
  • CREST syndrome
  • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Celiac disease

Inflammatory bowel disorders (ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease) is seen in patients with primary sclerosing cholangitis.

Related Pearl: Differences between primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) and primary biliary cholangitis (PBC)

  Primary Biliary Cholangitis Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis
Antibodies

Antimitochondrial antibodies positive in most patients

Antinuclear antibodies positive

Antimitochondrial antibodies /AMA typically negative

p-ANCA-positive
Age group 40–60 years 30-45 years
Gender predominance Females Males
Site Intrahepatic bile ducts only Intra- and extrahepatic bile ducts
 Associated with

Sjogren syndrome

Hashimoto's thyroiditis 

CREST syndrome

Rheumatoid arthritis

Celiac disease

 Ulcerative colitis
Diagnosis Biopsy MRCP/ERCP-strictures 
Biopsy findings  Florid duct lesion (granuloma) Concentric "onion-skin" fibrosis    
Long-term complication Cirrhosis

Cirrhosis

Cholangiocarcinoma

questions.text: During your internship, you notice the cylinder shown below, attached to an anesthetic machine present in the operation theater.  All of the following are the adverse effects of exposure to this inhalational agent, except _______.
questions.solution:
The given image shows a blue color cylinder, and these cylinders are used to store nitrous oxide. Iron-deficiency anemia is not a side effect of nitrous oxide.

Nitrous oxide inhibits vitamin B12-dependent enzymes like thymidylate synthase, which is necessary for DNA synthesis. This leads to megaloblastic bone marrow changes.

Megaloblastic anemia is seen with nitrous oxide, especially when exposure is greater than 2–6 hours (in healthy patients prolonged periods of exposure >12 hours are required whereas, in critically ill patients, much shorter periods of exposure can lead to megaloblastic changes in the bone marrow).

Other side effects of nitrous oxide:

  • Bone marrow depression
  • Subacute combined degeneration of the cord (myelinopathy)
  • Teratogenicity
  • Peripheral neuropathy

Contraindications of nitrous oxide:

  • Venous or arterial air embolism
  • Pneumothorax
  • Acute intestinal obstruction with bowel distention
  • Intracranial air (pneumocephalus following dural closure or pneumoencephalography)
  • Pulmonary air cysts
  • Intraocular air bubbles
  • Tympanic membrane grafting

Related Pearl: Unique features of Nitrous oxide

Concentration-effect

  • The blood gas partition coefficient of N2O is 35 times higher than O2 and N2, hence its rapid uptake diminishes its volume and concentrates the remaining anesthetics in the alveolus.

Second-gas effect

  • Concentration-effect of one gas over another is known as the second gas effect
  • Increase in the partial pressure of the 2nd gas (Oxygen and volatile agents) due to the rapid uptake of N2O during induction.

Diffusion hypoxia (Finks effect)

  • Rapid elimination of N2O during recovery causes a reduction in the partial pressure of oxygen leading to hypoxia
  • Avoided by using 100% oxygen for 10 minutes during recovery from anesthesia.

Nitrous oxide in gas-filled spaces

  • It diffuses into air-containing cavities more rapidly than air (principally nitrogen) can be absorbed by the bloodstream
  • If the walls surrounding the cavity are rigid, pressure rises instead of volume.

Hence N2O is contraindicated in:

  • Venous or arterial air embolism
  • Acute intestinal obstruction
  • Pneumocephalus, pneumothorax
  • Pulmonary air cysts
  • Intraocular air bubbles
  • Tympanic membrane grafting.

Related Pearl: Minimum alveolar concentration (MAC)

Minimum alveolar concentration (MAC) is the minimum concentration of an inhaled anesthetic at 1 atm of pressure that prevents skeletal muscle movement in response to a surgical incision in 50% of patients. 

MAC of inhaled anesthetics

Anesthetic Agents

MAC (Potency)

Blood-gas coefficient (Solubility)
Halothane 0.75  2.4
Isoflurane 1.2 1.4 
Enflurane 1.7 1.9 
Sevoflurane 2 0.65 
Desflurane 6 0.42 
Nitrous oxide 104 0.47 

MAC is an indicator of potency. The lower the MAC, the higher is the potency.

Related Pearl: Inhalational anaesthetic agents

Inhalational agent of choice: 

Indication Anesthetic gas
1. Induction  Sevoflurane
2. Daycare surgery Sevflurane>Desflurane
3. Elderly  Desflurane
4. Cardiac surgery Isoflurane
5. Renal disease Desflurane
6. Liver disease  Sevoflurane > Desflurane 
7. Neurosurgery    Sevoflurane>Isoflurane
8. Asthmatics Sevoflurane
9. Obese patients Desflurane

 

Feature Drug
Most potent       Methoxyflurane > Halothane 
Least potent      Nitrous oxide > Desflurane 
Most epileptogenic   Enflurane
Most nephrotoxic Methoxyflurane 
Most hepatotoxic Halothane

questions.text:
Match the following nail changes in psoriasis with their corresponding images.
  1. Oil drop sign
  2. Nail pitting
  3. Ridging
  4. Onycholysis with subungual keratosis
questions.solution:
The correct option matching the nail changes in psoriasis with the corresponding images is 1-C, 2-A, 3-D, and 4-B.

Any part of the nail unit may be affected. This includes the nail bed, nail matrix, and hyponychium.

Nail matrix disease presents with pits, ridges, and grooves in the nail plate. Pitting is the most frequent change seen in fingernails. 

Nail bed disease is seen as subungual ‘oil drops.’ It is highly specific for psoriasis. Other changes involving the nail bed include subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis.

Related Pearl: Nail changes in psoriasis

Nail changes in psoriasis are present in about 40% of the cases at any point in time. Nail psoriasis is associated with more extensive psoriasis, longer disease duration, family history of psoriasis, and the presence of psoriatic arthritis.

Subungal oil drop sign or Salmon Patch is a highly specific pathognomonic sign seen in Nail psoriasis. It is a yellow-red discoloration in the nail bed resembling a drop of oil.

Nail pitting however is the most frequent sign. Individual pits are uniformly sized, deep and irregular in nature. These nail pits are also known as Thimble pits and are due to the involvement of the proximal nail matrix.

Nail Bed disease also causes subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis.

Leuconychia may also be present.

Trachonychia or Twenty Nail dystrophy may be present in severe cases.

Image :  Pitting is the commonest manifestation of nail psoriasis.

Image: oil drops visible in the nail bed.

Image: pitting and salmon patches in fingernails.

Image: Leukonychia in a patient with psoriasis.

 

Features of Nail Psoriasis – Mnemonic

“Nail – POLISH”

  • P – Pitting
  • O – Oil drop sign, Onycholysis
  • L – Leuconychia
  • I – Irregular pitting pattern
  • S – Splinter Hemorrhage
  • H – Hyperkeratosis (Subungual)

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement regarding glucose transporters:

choices.text: GLUT2 is involved in transport of glucose out of enterocytes
SGLT1 is involved in absorption of glucose into the enterocytes
GLUT 4 is involved in the transport of fructose in the sperms
GLUT 2 acts as a beta cell glucose sensor in the islet cells

questions.solution:
The incorrect statement is option C. 

The transport of fructose in sperms is carried out by GLUT 5, not GLUT 4.

GLUT-5 is present in the small intestine, mature spermatids, kidneys, and brain. It is exclusively involved in the transport of fructose, with no ability to transport glucose or galactose. 

GLUT 4 is involved in insulin-stimulated glucose uptake in skeletal, cardiac, and adipose tissue. 

Other options:

Options A and D: GLUT2 acts as a beta cell glucose sensor in the islet cells of the pancreas and is also involved in the transport of glucose from the enterocyte into the interstitium or out of the enterocytes.

Option B: SGLT1 is involved in the absorption of glucose into the enterocyte. SGLT2 is responsible for glucose transport out of the renal tubules.

Related Pearl: Glucose Transporters

 

Function

Major sites of expression

Secondary active transport

(Na + -glucose cotransport)

    

SGLT 1

Absorption of glucose

Small intestine, renal tubules

SGLT 2

Absorption of glucose

Renal tubules

Facilitated diffusion

    

GLUT 1

Basal glucose uptake

Placenta, blood-brain barrier, brain, red cells, kidneys, colon, many other organs

GLUT 2

β-cell glucose sensor; transport out of intestinal and renal epithelial cells

β cells of islets, liver, epithelial cells of small intestine, kidneys

GLUT 3

Basal glucose uptake

Brain, placenta, kidneys, many other organs

GLUT 4

Insulin-stimulated glucose uptake

Skeletal and cardiac muscle, adipose tissue, other tissues

GLUT 5

Fructose transport

Jejunum, sperm

GLUT 6

 Function not known Brain, spleen, leucocytes
GLUT 7 Glucose-6-phosphate transporter in the endoplasmic reticulum Liver

questions.text: A  newborn male baby was found to have a very small occiput and posterior fossa. MRI imaging showed the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a baby with a very small occiput and posterior fossa and an image showing herniation of the cerebellar tonsils through the foramen magnum is suggestive of Chiari malformation. It is the most common malformation of the posterior fossa and hindbrain.

Children present with headaches that are worse with straining and other maneuvers that increase intracranial pressure. Symptoms of
brainstem compression, such as diplopia, oropharyngeal dysfunction, spasticity, tinnitus, sleep apnea, and vertigo, can occur due to brain stem compression. Incidental Chiari malformation with radiological findings compatible with Chiari malformation with no clinical manifestations of the disease is also seen. 

Chiari malformations are classified based on their morphology and severity of anatomic defects, typically through imaging or autopsy to Chiari I - Chiari IV. The Chiari I malformation is the most common type evaluated using magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), typically in a child or adult. Chiari II to IV malformations is often first evaluated by ultrasound in utero, with fetal MRI assessment performed for further characterization.

Muscle relaxants, NSAIDs, and the temporary use of a cervical collar are used to treat headaches and neck pain.  The main treatment for re-establishing the CSF flow across the craniovertebral junction and relieving pressure on the cerebellum and hindbrain by decompressing the posterior fossa in Chiari malformation is surgical. This can be achieved by a suboccipital craniectomy in conjunction with C1 and C2 laminectomy. 

Other options:

Option A- Mega cisterna magna/ Arachanoid cyst can also cause hydrocephalus. It is characterized by an enlarged CSF space inferior and dorsal to the cerebellar vermis. Persisting Blake pouch is a cyst that obstructs the subarachnoid space. 

The image below shows a CT of an arachnoid cyst. 

 

Option B- Joubert syndrome is an autosomal recessive ciliopathy associated with cerebellar vermis hypoplasia and molar tooth sign (a deepening of the interpeduncular fossa with thick and straight superior cerebellar peduncles). It is characterized by developmental delay, hypotonia, ataxia, breathing abnormalities including episodic apnea and hyperpnea.

The image below shows an MRI of Joubert syndrome demonstrating the molar tooth sign.  

 

Option C- Dandy-Walker syndrome is a congenital malformation that involves:

  • Cystic dilation of the fourth ventricle
  • Hypoplasia of the cerebellar vermis
  • Hydrocephalus
  • Enlargement of the posterior fossa.

The below MRI shows dilation of the fourth ventricle with hypoplasia of the cerebellar vermis.

questions.text:
Results of the quadruple screening test are tabulated below for three congenital anomalies. Choose the correctly matched set.
Parameter 1 2 3
Maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (MSAFP) Low Low High
 Human chorionic gonadotropin (β-hCG) High Low Normal
Unconjugated estriol Low Low Normal
Inhibin A High Normal/Low Normal
questions.solution:
Quadruple testing is done in the second trimester between 15-21 weeks of gestation and involves the following parameters:

  • Maternal serum alpha fetal protein (MSAFP) 
  • β hCG
  • Unconjugated estriol
  • Inhibin A
Parameter Trisomy 21/ Downs syndrome Trisomy 18/ Edward syndrome Neural tube defect or abdominal wall defect 
MSAFP Low Low High
β hCG High Low Normal
Unconjugated estriol Low Low Normal
Inhibin A High Normal/Low Normal

questions.text: A middle-aged woman develops hoarseness following a total thyroidectomy. On laryngoscopic examination, the left vocal cord is found to be in the cadaveric position. What is the best management in this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of unilateral complete vocal cord paralysis. The treatment of choice in this condition is speech therapy, if no improvement then medialization of the vocal cord is done.

Unilateral vocal cord paralysis is commonly seen following thyroid surgery (both recurrent and external laryngeal nerves of one side are affected). It results due to paralysis of all the muscles of the larynx on one side, except the inter arytenoid, which receives innervation from the opposite side.

The vocal cord will assume the cadaveric position, i.e., 3.5 mm from the midline. The healthy cord is unable to approximate the paralyzed cord, thus causing glottic incompetence, resulting in hoarseness of voice and aspiration of liquids through the glottis.

Treatment includes speech therapy and medialization of vocal cords by injection of Teflon paste lateral to the paralyzed cord (type I thyroplasty).

Thyroplasty is a surgery done to improve the quality of voice. Isshiki's classification of thyroplasty includes:

  • Type I: It is the medialization of the vocal cord. This is done in unilateral vocal cord palsy. (option B)
  • Type II: It is lateralization of the vocal cord and is used to improve the airway. This is done in bilateral abductor palsy. (option A)
  • Type III: It is used to shorten or relax the vocal cord. This is done in those who have undergone gender transformation from female to male.
  • Type IV: It is used to lengthen or tighten the vocal cord and elevate the pitch. This is done in those who have undergone gender transformation from male to female.

Other options:

Options A and C: Tracheostomy and lateralization of the vocal cord (type 2 thyroplasty) are done in case of bilateral abductor paralysis. Patients usually present with dyspnea and stridor. Both the cords lie in the median or paramedian position compromising the airway.

Option D: Epiglottopexy is the procedure done for bilateral vocal cord paralysis. Patients present with cough and choking fits due to inhalation of food and pharyngeal secretions.

Related Pearl: Various Vocal Cord Palsies

Type of palsy U/L Abductor B/L Abductor U/L complete B/L complete
Nerve RLN (left) Both RLNs RLN+SLN (left) Both RLN+SLN
Cord position Paramedian   |\ Both in  Paramedian   || Cadaveric   [\ cadaveric (intermediate) position [[
Voice Hoarse Good Hoarse Aphonia
Dyspnea - + - -
Aspiration - - +/- +
Treatment Wait & watch (palsy with least consequences) Tracheostomy, lateralization Wait & watch, medialization Tracheostomy + Epiglottopexy

Guide: \ is normal moving cord; | is paramedian; [ is cadaveric.

Related Pearl: Positions of the Vocal Cord

Position Distance from median Seen in
Median 0 During speech/ swallowing
Paramedian 1 mm Recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy
Intermediate/ Cadaveric 3 mm Complete paralysis
Slight abduction 7 mm Normal respiration
Full abduction 9 mm Strained respiration

Related Pearl: Nerves of Larynx

questions.text: A 19-year-old male patient presents to the OPD with complaints of progressive swelling in his left arm. An X-ray of the patient is given below. Which of the following statements is true regarding the management of this condition?

choices.text: Radiotherapy is mandatory as it is a highly radiosensitive tumor
Cisplatin  is the chemotherapeutic agent of choice
The goal of neoadjuvant and adjuvant chemotherapy is to treat micro metastasis.
Hindquarter amputation is indicated in tumors involving upper end of tibia

questions.solution:
The X-ray showing periosteal lifting and sunburst appearance is suggestive of osteosarcoma and the goal of neoadjuvant and adjuvant chemotherapy in osteosarcoma is to treat micro-metastasis.

Osteosarcoma is the most common non-hematologic primary malignancy of bone. It occurs most commonly in the second decade of life. It is typically metaphyseal.

The distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus are the common sites. 

In osteosarcoma, the tumor lifts the periosteum and incites an intense periosteal reaction. The periosteal reaction is irregular and it may take the form of a "Codman's triangle" or it may have a "sunburst (sunray) appearance" on X-ray.

The image given in question shows the following features:

  • Irregular destruction in the metaphysis overshadowed by the formation of new bone
  • Lifting of the periosteum due to the formation of new bone inciting a periosteal reaction
  • Bone formation along the blood vessels within the tumor centrifugally giving rise to "sunburst (sunray) appearance" on the radiograph.

Treatment:

Osteosarcoma is treated by neoadjuvant chemotherapy, wide excision or radical surgery followed by adjuvant chemotherapy. Since here safe margins are difficult to achieve limb ablation is done. 

Osteosarcoma is a radioresistant tumor

The goal of neoadjuvant and adjuvant chemotherapy is to treat micrometastasis.

T-10 protocol of chemotherapy is used in the management of osteosarcoma. It involves:

  • High dose methotrexate and Citrovorum factor rescue
  • Adriamycin
  • BCD (bleomycin, cyclophosphamide, dactinomycin/doxorubicin)

Note:

Levels of amputation in osteosarcoma:

Upper end of humerus Forequarter amputation
Upper end of tibia Midthigh amputation
Upper end of femur Hindquarter amputation and hip disarticulation
Lower end of femur Midthigh amputation and hip disarticulation

Related Pearl: Classical Radiological Appearance of Bone Tumors

RADIOLOGICAL APPEARANCE 

TUMORS

Sunray appearance / Codman’s triangle

Osteosarcoma (but can be seen in any malignant lesion)

Onion peel appearance 

Ewing’s sarcoma (but can be seen in any malignant lesion or chronic osteomyelitis)

Soap bubble appearance 

Giant cell tumor, adamantinoma 

Ground glass appearance / Shepherd's

crook deformity 

Fibrous dysplasia 

Patchy calcification 

Chondrogenic tumors (chondrosarcoma and chondroblastoma)

Popcorn, punctate or comma-shaped calcification

Chondrosarcoma 

Stippled or Punctate calcification

Chondroblastoma 

Homogeneous calcification 

Osteogenic tumors (osteosarcoma)

Fallen fragment / Trap door sign

Simple bone cyst

Double-density fluid levels and intra-lesional septation

Aneurysmal bone cyst

Winking owl sign

Vertebral metastasis 

Polka dot sign / Corduroy / Jailhouse sign

Vertebral hemangioma

Moth eaten bone

Multiple myeloma

Related Pearl: Summary of Bone Tumors

Bone tumor Most common site Age

Enchondroma

(Metaphysis of small bones of hand)

4th & 5th

Decade

(Exostosis)

2nd & 3rd

decade

decade

Decade

questions.text: Which of the following Filariae exhibit a diurnal periodicity?
questions.solution:
Loa Loa exhibits diurnal periodicity, that peaks between 10:00 a.m. and 2:00 p.m.

The microfilariae are found in large numbers in the peripheral blood during specific times of the day, depending on the blood-feeding habits of their insect vector. This is known as periodicity. Filarial worms can exhibit nocturnal, diurnal periodicity, or no periodicity at all.

  • Nocturnal periodicity: When the largest number of microfilariae are present in the blood at night. Eg- Wuchereria bancrofti, Brugia malayi, Brugia timori
  • Diurnal periodicity: When the largest number of microfilariae occur in blood during the day. Eg- Loa loa
  • Nonperiodic: When the number of microfilariae maintains a constant level during the day and night. Eg- Onchocerca volvulus
  • Subperiodic or nocturnally subperiodic: When the microfilariae can be detected in the blood throughout the day but are detected in larger numbers in the late afternoon or at night. Eg- Wuchereria bancrofti in the eastern pacific and Brugia malayi in Indonesia and southeast Asia.

The nematode worm Loa loa causes skin and eye disease called Loa loa filariasis. Humans contract this disease through the bite of a Chrysops fly, commonly called deer fly or mango fly, which are the vectors for Loa loa. It is shown in the image below.

 

The adult Loa loa filarial worm migrates throughout the subcutaneous tissues of humans. Subconjunctival migration of an adult worm to the eyes can occur frequently, and this is the reason Loa loa is also called the "African eye worm." 

They mature to adult worms in approximately one year, but sometimes up to four years. Adult worms migrate in the subcutaneous tissues at a speed less than 1 cm/min, mating and producing more microfilariae. The adult worms can live up to 17 years in the human host.

Diagnosis of loiasis:

  • Characteristic history and presentation with eosinophilia, and elevated levels of antifilarial antibodies, particularly in travelers to an endemic region
  • Detection of microfilariae in the peripheral blood 
  • Isolation of the adult worm from the eye or a subcutaneous biopsy from a swelling 
  • PCR-based assays for the detection of L. loa DNA in blood

Treatment: DEC (8–10 mg/kg per day administered orally for 21 days) is effective. Heavy infections can be treated initially with apheresis to remove the microfilariae, glucocorticoids, and DEC.

The image below shows a live adult Loa loa worm in the anterior chamber of the eye.

questions.text: A patient is undergoing Doppler ultrasonographic assessment for varicose veins. When the probe was placed inferior to the inguinal crease, the sign shown in the below image was seen on the transverse view in the B-mode. What does it indicate?
questions.solution:
The sign in the image given above is the Mickey mouse sign, which represents the normal anatomy of the femoral vessels.

The Mickey mouse sign is seen on the transverse B-mode of USG.

It includes 

  • Great saphenous vein (GSV),
  • Common femoral vein (CFV), and
  • Common femoral artery (CFA)

Normally, the GSV and CFV lie medial to the common femoral artery, which gives rise to the sign.

Mickey mouse in medicine:

  • Mickey mouse appearance - seen on antenatal ultrasound, due to absent cranial bone/brain and bulging orbits in anencephaly
  • Mickey mouse appearance - seen on MRI in progressive supranuclear palsy
  • The Mickey Mouse sign also represents the configuration of the portal triad - the portal vein, common bile duct, and the hepatic artery on biliary ultrasound.

questions.text:
A full-term infant with a history of polyhydramnios in utero presents with respiratory distress soon after birth. On examination frothing at the mouth is observed and the child regurgitates the feeds given to him. Abdominal examination reveals an airless scaphoid abdomen. A contrast study is performed and the findings are as shown below. Which of the following statements given about the condition is false?
  1. The condition can be diagnosed immediately by trying to pass an orogastric tube.
  2. More than 90% of these are associated with VACTERL defects.
  3. An air-filled abdomen must raise the suspicion of associated type H tracheo-oesophageal fistula.
  4. The child may develop severe reactive airway disease.
  5. The current standard surgical therapy includes right-sided thoracotomy.
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette with the radiograph depicting a defect in the contrast study is suggestive of oesophagal atresia (EA). Isolated oesophagal atresia falls under tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF) type A. The incorrect statements include 2 and 3 only.

More than 90% of oesophageal atresia is most commonly associated with TEF (Tracheo-oesophageal fistula). If on examination the child has an air-filled abdomen it should raise the suspicion of TEF, the most common type being type - C. 

Type H - isolated TEF (without esophageal atresia) seldom presents with such symptoms and can be diagnosed with an esophagogram with contrast medium.It can present later in life with chronic respiratory problems like refractory bronchospasm and recurrent pneumonias.

 

The image below gives Gross classification of TEF.

Oesophageal atresia:

  • Oesophagal atresia (EA) is the most common congenital anomaly of the oesophagus
  • In the most common form of EA, the proximal oesophagus ends in a blind pouch and a tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF) connects to the distal oesophagus.
  • Infants with EA have a > 90% chance of survival due to improved neonatal intensive care, early diagnosis, and intervention.
  • >90% of infants with EA are associated with TEF ( Not VACTERL anomalies). About 50 % of infants with EA have associated anomalies of which VACTERL syndrome is most common.

Clinical features:

  • Drooling of saliva, inability to pass a nasogastric tube and history of polyhydramnios suggests a diagnosis of oesophagal atresia with or without TEF.

  • Indicators of oesophagal atresia with or without a tracheo-oesophagal fistula (TEF) are a newborn presenting with:

    • Early-onset respiratory distress
    • Frothing at the mouth and nose
    • History of polyhydramnios
  • If an air-distended stomach is also present, it indicates the presence of a coexisting TEF.
  • Pure EA can manifest as an airless scaphoid abdomen.

Diagnosis:

This can be confirmed with a chest X-ray image showing a coiled nasogastric tube in the oesophagal pouch. 

Complications:

  • Very commonly, reactive airway disease in the form of pneumonitis due to GERD.
  • Aspiration pneumonitis.

Treatment:

Gold standard treatment includes - Right-sided extra pleural thoracotomy.

Order of frequency:

Type C (most common) > Type B > Type E (or H)

Related Pearl: Types of Tracheo-esophageal Fistula/Esophageal Atresia

Abbreviations:

  • EA: Esophageal atresia
  • TEF: Tracheo-esophageal Fistula

questions.text:
Your professor explains a phenomenon wherein there is worsening of angina due to marked vasodilation of the coronary arteries in the non-ischemic zones in patients with partial obstruction of coronary arteries. Which of the following drugs cause this phenomenon?
  1. Dipyridamole
  2. Desflurane
  3. Adenosine
  4. Regadenoson
questions.solution:
The stem explains the coronary steal phenomenon. 1, 3, and 4 cause this phenomenon.

Coronary steal phenomenon :

In patients with partial obstruction of coronary vasculature, a region of ischemia develops in the myocardium. In the absence of drugs, arterioles in the ischemic areas are usually maximally dilated as a result of local compensatory mechanisms. 

When a nonselective arteriolar dilator is administered, it can only dilate the vessels of the normal myocardium as the vessels of the ischemic myocardium are already maximally dilated. This diverts (steals) the blood away from the ischemic myocardium towards the normal myocardium. This is termed as coronary steal phenomenon.

Drugs causing Coronary steal phenomenon:

  • Dipyridamole
  • Adenosine
  • Regadenoson

questions.text: In a patient undergoing cataract surgery, which of the following is the most important strategy in the prevention of postoperative endophthalmitis?

choices.text: One week antibiotic therapy prior to surgery

questions.solution:
The most important factor in the prevention of postoperative endophthalmitis is preoperative preparation with povidone-iodine. 

Postoperative endophthalmitis is most commonly caused by Staphylococcus epidermidis. Flora of the eyelids and conjunctiva are the most frequent source. Other potential sources include contaminated solutions and instruments, environmental air, and the surgeon and other operating room personnel.

Prophylaxis for postoperative endophthalmitis includes: 

  • Instillation of 5% povidone-iodine into the conjunctival fornices and leaving this undisturbed for at least 3 minutes prior to surgery. This is the most important factor. 
  • Scrupulous preparation of the surgical site
  • Treatment of pre-existing infections such as blepharitis
  • Antibiotic prophylaxis
    • Intracameral cefuroxime (1 mg in 0.1 mL) injected into the anterior chamber (AC) at the end of surgery.
    • Post-operative subconjunctival injection can achieve bactericidal levels in the AC for at least 1–2 hours.
    • Preoperative topical fluoroquinolone antibiotics are frequently given in regimens from 1 hour to 3 days before surgery

Patients present with ocular pain, diminished vision, circumciliary congestion and hypopyon. The differential diagnosis for postoperative endophthalmitis includes retained lens material in the AC, vitreous hemorrhage, postoperative uveitis and toxic reaction to the use of inappropriate or contaminated irrigating fluid or viscoelastic.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a characteristic feature of a patient with Tourette's syndrome?

choices.text: Persistence of tics for at least 6 months
Presence of at least one vocal tic

questions.solution:
Tourette's syndrome is diagnosed when there is a persistence of tics for at least 1 year.

According to DSM-5 criteria, a diagnosis of Tourette's disorder depends on:

  • A history of multiple motor tics and the emergence of at least one vocal tic at some point.
  • Tics may wax and wane in frequency but must have persisted for more than a year.
  • The average age of onset of tics is between 4 years and 6 years of age, although the peak age for the severity of tics is between 10 and 12 years.
  • The onset of symptoms must occur before the age of 18 years. No tic-free period of more than three consecutive months in 1 year.

questions.text: Dangerous placenta previa is a variation of :
questions.solution:
Dangerous placenta previa is a variation of type II placenta previa(option b). It is the name given to the type-II posterior placenta previa.

It is so called :

  • Because of the curved birth canal, the major thickness of the placenta (about 2.5cm) overlies the sacral promontory, thereby diminishing the anteroposterior diameter of the inlet and prevents the engagement of the presenting part. This hinders effective compression of the separated placenta to stop bleeding.
  • The placenta is more likely to be compressed if vaginal delivery is allowed.
  • More chance of cord compression or cord prolapse.

The last two may produce fetal anoxia or even death.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked by the red arrow in the dissected specimen of the dorsum of the hand:
questions.solution:
The structure marked is the extensor pollicis longus tendon. It forms the medial boundary of the anatomical snuffbox.

An anatomical snuffbox is a triangular depression on the posterolateral side of the wrist. It is best observed when the thumb is extended. Its boundaries are:

Lateral wall Abductor pollicis longus (APL)
Extensor pollicis brevis (EPB)
Medial wall Extensor pollicis longus (EPL)
Roof Cephalic vein
Superficial branch of radial nerve
Floor Radial styloid, scaphoid, trapezium, and 1st metacarpal
Content Radial artery

 

The image below shows the tendons seen on the dissection of the dorsum of the hand.

questions.text: A 65 year old man was admitted with generalised weakness, easy fatigability, itching and jaundice since 1 month. On examination, he was emaciated and had scratch marks all over the body. A mass was palpable in the upper abdomen. Which of the following can be seen on Van den Bergh reaction?
questions.solution:
Generalised weakness, easy fatigability, itching and jaundice with a palpable upper abdominal mass is suggestive of pancreatic malignancy leading to obstructive jaundice. This gives a direct positive result on Van den Bergh reaction.

In obstructive jaundice, obstruction of the biliary tree causes regurgitation of conjugated bilirubin into the blood. Patients present with itching, jaundice and pale coloured stools.

Van den Bergh reaction is a colorimetric method to measure the serum bilirubin level. It is based on the formation of red azodipyrroles when diazotized sulfanilic acid reacts with bilirubin.

Clinical condition Reaction with reagent Interpretation
Normal serum No reaction Negative
High conjugated bilirubin
eg: Obstructive jaundice		 Reacts in the absence of methanol Direct positive
High unconjugated bilirubin
eg: Hemolytic anemia		 Reacts in the presence of methanol Indirect positive
High conjugated and unconjugated bilirubin
eg: Hepatic jaundice		 Reacts strongly both with and without methanol Biphasic reaction

questions.text: A 25-year-old lady who was a victim of rape was brought by the lady constable to the gynecologist for examination. The doctor examined the victim and obtained a sample in and around the vagina. Which among the following statements is false regarding this situation?

choices.text: Seminal stains can be detected by ultraviolet light
Acid phosphatase test can be used to detect seminal stain
Absence of spermatozoa in the sample collected excludes rape
Vaginal and cervical cells can be identified from the penis of the accused using papanicolaou's stain

questions.solution:
Absence of spermatozoa in the sample obtained does not exclude rape.

The seminal fluid may have been removed by washing, or discharges or there may not have been an emission, or it may have been aspermic, or ejaculation occured outside.

Other options:

  • Seminal stains can be detected by ultraviolet light
  • An acid phosphatase test is used to identify seminal stains: The prostatic secretion contains acid phosphatase. Semen recovered from the vagina retains acid phosphatase concentrations upto 36 hours after it's deposition. It is expressed in Bodansky units. Acid phosphatase test is conclusive in case the absence of demonstrable sperms or Aspermia. The absolute proof of semen is finding at least one unbroken spermatozoon or electrophoretic LDH isoenzyme detection of sperms.
  • The suspect's penis is washed with saline and the material is stained with papanicolao's stain. Vaginal and cervical cells and barrbody identification suggest recent intercourse.

Related Pearl: Tests to detect seminal and blood stains

Tests for seminal stains

  • Barberio's test
  • Florence test
  • Acid phosphatase test
  • Creatine phosphokinase test
  • Immunological test to detect Prostate Specific Antigen

Tests for blood stains  

  • Benzidine test
  • Phenophthalein (Kastle Meyer) test
  • Takayama hemochromogen crystal test
  • Teichmann’s hemin crystal test
  • Spectroscopic test

questions.text: A study was conducted to compare the incidence of postpartum depression in mothers as compared to the sex of the child. For assessment, Edinburg Depression scaled score (EDSS) was used. The study was divided into mothers with male babies as one group to be compared with mothers with female babies. Which of the following statistical test will be used to determine the association?
questions.solution:
The Chi-square test is used to compare qualitative data and compares 2 groups with independent measures. The variables used here are yes/no signifying the presence/absence of postpartum depression. Hence it is the most appropriate test here.

Option A: Student’s t-test is for quantitative data. Here the data is qualitative, hence it can't be used.

Option B: Paired t-test compares paired data or pre-intervention and post-intervention data of the same group. This doesn't apply here as the groups are not paired.

Option C: ANOVA is used to compare more than 2 groups.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient has NYHA class III heart failure with dyspnea, pedal edema and K+ levels of 5.5 mg% and creatinine 1.1 mg%. Which of the following drugs can be used in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario describes a patient with symptomatic heart failure and K+ levels of 5.5 mg%. She requires a diuretic for symptom control. Furosemide can be given safely as it causes hypokalemia.

Other options:

Option A: Digoxin is not used as a first-line drug in the management of symptomatic heart failure.

Options B and C: Spironolactone (K+ sparing diuretic) and enalapril (ACE inhibitor) can cause hyperkalemia.  

The first step in managing acute decompensated heart failure (ADHF) is addressing the factors that caused the decompensation. They include nonadherence to medications, dietary indiscretion, medication use that exacerbates heart failure, coronary ischemia, arrhythmias, valvular heart disease, infection, and pulmonary thromboembolism.

Volume management is crucial in ADHF. Intravenous loop diuretics are used to relieve congestion. The effectiveness of diuretic therapy can be assessed by changes in weight, improvement in symptoms, and clinical examination findings. Natriuretic peptide levels can also help assess the adequacy of therapy and predict risk.

Cardiorenal syndrome, characterized by the interplay between heart and kidney dysfunction, is a common complication of ADHF. Diuretic therapy should be carefully managed to avoid worsening renal function in patients with elevated right-sided filling pressures. In cases of severe low cardiac output, inotropic therapy or mechanical circulatory support may be necessary to preserve or improve renal function temporarily.

Vasodilators like nitroglycerin, sodium nitroprusside, and nesiritide (recombinant BNP) are used to reduce filling pressures and systemic vascular resistance. 

Inotropic therapy with drugs like dopamine and milrinone is used to increase myocardial contractility and improve cardiac output in patients with low-output ADHF. Dopamine has dose-dependent effects on different receptors, while milrinone is a phosphodiesterase-3 inhibitor.

Related Pearl: Drugs used in heart failure

Drugs used in acute decompensated heart failure:
 
Intravenous vasodilators

Nitroglycerine

Sodium nitroprusside

 Decrease preload and afterload
Nesiritide Recombinant human BNP
 
Intravenous positive inotropes

Dobutamine

Dopamine

Epinephrine

Norepinephrine

 β1 receptor-mediated stimulation of cardiac output

Enoximone

Milrinone

 PDE 3/4 inhibitors

Levosimendan

Pimobendan

 Combined Ca2+ sensitizers and PDE3 inhibitors
 
Drugs used for rapid symptom relief

Bumetanide

Furosemide

Torasemide

 Loop diuretics- used for symptomatic treatment of severe heart failure and acute decompensation.
Morphine Opioid - to calm the patient and decreases cardiac O2 consumption
 
Drugs used in chronic heart failure:
Drugs Uses
ACE inhibitors Used as first-line therapy
ARBs Used in case of intolerance to ACE inhibitors
Beta-blockers Used as first-line therapy  

Spironolactone

Eplerenone

 Mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists - first-line drugs for symptomatic heart failure.
SGLT-2 inhibitors Used as 1st line therapy- reduces mortality and morbidity
Sacubitril/Valsartan Neprilysin inhibitor/ARB(ARNI)
Ivabradine Inhibitor of If current in the sinoatrial node
